<table border="0" width="100%"> <tbody> <tr> <td align="center" rowspan="2"> <a href="index.html"><img border="0" alt="Hello World" title="Hello World" hspace="10" src="HelloWorld.tall.png" width="120" height="144" align="middle"/></a> <br /> <br /> <a href="HelloCostaRicaX3dom.xhtml" target="_blank"><img border="0" alt="Hello Costa Rica" title="Hello Costa Rica" hspace="10" src="images/HelloCostaRica.png" width="120" height="50" align="middle"/></a> <br /> <br /> <a href="HelloGermanyX_ITE.html" target="_blank"><img border="0" alt="Hello Germany" title="Hello Germany" hspace="10" src="images/HelloGermanyX_ITE.png" width="120" height="83" align="middle"/></a> </td> <td align="left"> <p> This chapter holds a collection of interesting variations on the original <a href="HelloWorld.x3d">HelloWorld.x3d</a> reference scene using many different languages, thus testing foreign-language support by HTML browsers and X3D players. The <i>Hello&nbsp;World</i> scene itself was inspired as a basic test that follows a common pattern, demonstrating the simplest possible way to say "<code>Hello&nbsp;World</code>" in a given programming language. You might know that there are many such programs for many different programming languages. VRML and X3D are both illustrated on the <a href="http://en.wikibooks.org/w/index.php?title=Computer_Programming/Hello_world" target="_blank">Hello World Wikipedia page</a> as part of several hundred programming languages. </p> <p> X3D scene models typically use the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UTF-8">UTF-8 character encoding</a> which is capable of representing all possible characters used in human languages. Of further interest is <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internationalization_and_localization" target="_blank">Internationalization (I18N) and Localization (L10N)</a> on the Web, which is the use of different languages in documents. Lots of work is ongoing as part of the <a href="http://www.w3.org/International" target="_blank">W3C Internationalization (i18n) Activity</a>. XML provides excellent I18N support for the Web. The <a href="https://www.web3d.org/files/specifications/19775-1/V3.3/Part01/components/text.html#Concepts" target="X3D">X3D Text component</a> allows authors to specify the use of numerous different <i>language</i> encodings, along with corresponding <i>justify</i> field for vertical and horizontal line alignment ("FIRST" "BEGIN" "MIDDLE" "END"), of text directions for <i>horizontal</i>/vertical, <i>leftToRight</i>/right-to-left and <i>topToBottom</i>/bottom-to-top, font <i>family</i> ("SANS" "SERIF" "TYPEWRITER" or other), font <i>style</i> (PLAIN BOLD ITALIC BOLDITALIC), etc. Thus the <a href="https://www.web3d.org/files/specifications/19775-1/V3.3/Part01/Architecture.html" target="X3D">X3D Graphics International Standard</a> also provides excellent I18N support for any human language on the Web. </p> <p> <a href="https://www.web3d.org/realtime-3d/news/internationalization-x3d" target="_blank">Call for contributions</a>! If you are interested in contributing a Hello World scene scene for your country or location, that is great. Please post it to the <a href="mailto:x3d-public@web3d.org?subject=Hello%20World%20scene%20contribution%20">x3d-public@web3d.org</a> mailing list or else <a href="http://x3dgraphics.com/contact.php" target="_blank">contact us</a> directly. Have fun with X3D! </p> </td> <td align="center"> <a href="HelloSeoulX3dom.xhtml"><img border="0" alt="Hello Seoul" title="Hello Seoul" hspace="10" src="images/HelloSeoul.png" width="120" height="88.6" align="middle"/></a> <br /> <br /> <a href="HelloTaiwanX3dom.xhtml" target="_blank"><img border="0" alt="Hello Taiwan" title="Hello Taiwan" hspace="10" src="images/HelloTaiwan.png" width="120" height="82" align="middle"/></a> </td> </tr> </tbody> </table>
